WRITING.TEXT: exif data says it's a picture taken today on a samsung galaxy pocket

What I figured is the xml is dynamically updated with about 5 short clips of about 30 seconds in .ts format, which replace the previous clips. So basically the whole 5-6 day long video has been cut up in short bits of 30 seconds. And that's why when you increase the speed (in some browsers) it stops after a while until the next set of 5 or 6 videos are available in the xml.
No I've been analyzing the code and the last modified date is not in the future. The code doesn't work that way: check my post

WRITING.TITLE: How I know the "stream" is pre-recorded but not a loop at the same time
WRITING.TEXT: I looked into the source code of the website and it leads to [this](http://live-promotions.apple.com/). For those of you, who understand even the slightest of tech: this is an xml file. It contains the playlist (.m3u8) to all the different versions of the feed (640p, 960p blah blah) and this playlist is updated dynamically with about 4 or 5 short video files of about 20 to 30 seconds each in the format (.ts). This is precisely the reason that you can speed up the video in some browsers (for example Edge.) In all technicality, this is "endless" meaning the whole video would be 3 or 4 days long that is ONE endless shot but cut up into small segments of about 20 to 30 seconds. Now I'm no hacker but this was pretty easy to figure out. The future of the stream is stored somewhere in some server belonging to Apple.
